skills.name: Read values off a real life graph

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have assumed that every 1 mile travelled costs Â£1 but the graph doesn't show this. Which axis shows distance travelled? Can you find 30 miles? Can you read off the corresponding amount?
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for distance travelled. The horizontal axis (x-axis) is the one that shows distance travelled.
explanations.C: Be careful. Have a look again. Start counting up from Â£20 until you hit the line.
explanations.D: To find the amount Kay's company paid her for travel we find 30 miles on the ğ‘¥ axis, and draw a vertical line up to the line on the graph. We draw another line at this point to meet the ğ‘¦ axis and read off. This reads Â£24.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for distance travelled. The horizontal (x-axis) is the one that shows distance travelled.
explanations.B: Be careful. Have a look again. Do we go up one square until we get to Â£10?
explanations.C: To find the amount Kay's company paid her for travel we find 10 miles on the ğ‘¥ axis, and draw a vertical line up to the line on the graph. We draw another line at this point to meet the ğ‘¦ axis and read off. This reads Â£8.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have assumed that every 1 mile travelled costs Â£1 but the graph doesn't show this. Which axis shows distance travelled? Can you find 10 miles? Can you read off the corresponding amount?

explanations.A: Be careful. Have a look again. Using a ruler to read down to the axis can help with accuracy.
explanations.B: The graph shows that if Kay was paid Â£20 then she would have travelled 25 miles. Multiplying both of these by 4 (20 âœ• 4 = 80) tells us that if Kay got paid Â£80 she would have travelled 100 miles.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for amount paid. The vertical axis (y-axis) is the one that shows the amount of money Kay gets paid for any distance travelled.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have assumed that every 1 mile travelled costs Â£1 but the graph doesn't show this. How far can Kay travel if the company pays her Â£20? Can you use this to work out how far Kay travelled if the company paid her Â£80?

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for amount paid. The vertical axis (y-axis) is the one that shows the amount of money Kay gets paid for any distance travelled.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have assumed that every 1 mile travelled costs Â£1 but the graph doesn't show this. How far can Kay travel if the company pays her Â£20? Can you use this to work out how far Kay travelled if the company paid her Â£100?
explanations.C: The graph shows that if Kay was paid Â£20 then she would have travelled 25 miles. Multiplying both of these by 5 (20 âœ• 5 = 100) tells us that if Kay got paid Â£100 she would have travelled 125 miles.
explanations.D: Be careful. Have a look again. Using a ruler to read down to the axis can help with accuracy.

explanations.A: Not quite! 15 minutes is when Molly started walking again. Remember, when Molly stops walking she is remaining the same distance from home, her distance is not increasing. At what time does this start to happen?
explanations.B: We can tell where she stopped as this is where the graph is flat, and this happened at 10 minutes.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for time taken. The horizontal axis (x-axis) is the one that shows the time. The 1 is telling us that she is 1km from home when she stops.
explanations.D: Not quite! Remember, when Molly stops walking she is remaining the same distance from home, her distance is not increasing. At what time does this start to happen?

explanations.A: The horizontal line shows the times where she has stopped. As the line goes up again at 15 minutes, we know she starts again at 15 minutes.
explanations.B: Not quite! 10 minutes is when Molly stopped walking. Remember, when Molly starts walking again her distance from home starts to increase again. At what time does this start to happen after she stopped?
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have used the wrong axis for time taken. The horizontal axis (x-axis) is the one that shows the time. The 1 is telling us that she is 1km from home when she stops.
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you found how long she stopped for! Remember, when Molly starts walking again her distance from home starts to increase again. At what time does this start to happen after she stopped?

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have seen the graph starts on the y-axis at Â£10 and assumed this was the cost per mile. This Â£10 is the fixed cost, as it has to be paid even if the customer travels 0 miles. The cost for every additional mile can be found by comparing two distances and their corresponding costs.
explanations.B: Not quite! The cost for every additional mile can be found by comparing two distances and their corresponding costs. How much does it cost to travel 10 miles? How much does it cost to travel 20 miles? How many additional miles is this? How much does it cost to travel these additional miles? Can you share this between each additional mile?
explanations.C: Be careful! Every large square on the x-axis is 5 miles not 1.
explanations.D:
The cost of travelling 10 miles is Â£20. The cost of travelling 20 miles is Â£30. To travel these extra 10 miles you are charged Â£10. To find the additional cost per mile we divide. 10 Ã· 10 = 1.
Therefore it costs Â£1 for every additional mile travelled. This is the gradient of the graph.

explanations.A: The additional cost is the gradient of the graph, we find this by comparing two points on the graph. For 0 minutes used the cost is Â£20. For 500 minutes used the cost is Â£35. This is an additional Â£15 for an extra 500 minutes used. The cost for every additional minute is found by dividing. 15 Ã· 500 = 0.03. Therefore it costs Â£0.03 for every additional minute.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have done the division the wrong way around. 33.33 is the additional number of minutes you get for every Â£1 spent. We want to calculate the additional cost for every extra minute.
explanations.C: Be careful! I think you have seen that the graph goes across five and therefore divided 35 by 5, but the x-axis is labelled using 100's not 1's.
explanations.D: Not quite! It looks like you have found the fixed cost (the cost the calls start at). To calculate the additional cost we need to find the cost for two different lengths of calls, and then compare the costs and the number of minutes. Then you can find the cost per minute

explanations.A:
Not quite! I think you have seen that 400 units costs Â£55 and then doubled. But as Lethna is being charged two different rates so we cannot do this.
The graph shows us that Lethna pays Â£25 for the first 100 units. How much does she pay per 100 units after this? How many units charged at this rate has she used?
explanations.B: The graph shows us that Lethna pays Â£25 for the first 100 units. She pays a further Â£10 per 100 units. We add Â£20 onto Â£75 to get Â£95 for 800 units as the graph only shows us to 600 units.
explanations.C:
Not quite! I think you have seen that for the first 100 units used Lethna is charged Â£25 and then multiplied this by 8, but Lethna is charged a different rate after the first 100 units.
How much does she pay per 100 units after the first 100? .
explanations.D: Not quite! The graph shows us that Lethna pays Â£25 for the first 100 units. How much does she pay per 100 units after this? How many units at this additional rate does she use?

explanations.A:
Not quite! I think you have seen that 500 units costs Â£65 and then doubled. But as Lethna is being charged two different rates so we cannot do this.
The graph shows us that Lethna pays Â£25 for the first 100 units. How much does she pay per 100 units after this? How many units charged at this rate has she used?
explanations.B:
Not quite! I think you have seen that for the first 100 units used Lethna is charged Â£25 and then multiplied this by 10, but Lethna is charged a different rate after the first 100 units.
How much does she pay per 100 units after the first 100? How many units charged at this rate has she used?
explanations.C: After the first100 units, 100 units costs Â£10. An extra 400 units will cost 4 Ã— Â£10 = Â£40, so we can add that to the cost of 600 units, which gives Â£75 + Â£40 = Â£115.
explanations.D: Not quite! The graph shows us that Lethna pays Â£25 for the first 100 units. How much does she pay per 100 units after this? How many units at this additional rate does she use?
